content.text: Adjust the pendulum until its length \(l = 30.0 \text{cm}\). The length \(l\) is measured to the centre of the bob

Displace the pendulum bob slightly from its vertical position and release it so that it swings. Measure and record in Table 1.1 the time \(t\) for 20 complete oscillations of the pendulum (see Fig. 1.2)
Calculate the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation
Record the value of \(T\) in the table
Adjust the length of the pendulum until its length \(l = 60.0 \text{cm}\). Repeat steps **(b)** and **(c)**
A student suggests that doubling the length \(l\) of the pendulum should double period \(T\)
State whether your results support this suggestion and justify your answer by reference to the results
statement
justification
Another student suggests that \(l\) should be directly proportional to \(T^2\). The student plots a graph of \(l\) against \(T^2\)
State two pieces of information from the graph that would indicate that \(l\) is directly proportional to \(T^2\)
Remove the pendulum and replace it with the other pendulum provided. This pendulum has a mass that is double the mass of the first pendulum
Adjust the length of the pendulum until its length \(l = 30.0 \text{cm}\). Repeat steps **(b)** and **(c)**. Record the readings in Table 1.2
Suggest a conclusion about the effect of doubling the mass of the pendulum
In this experiment, you will investigate pendulums
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Figs. 1.1 and 1.2
A pendulum has been set up for you

Pour approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water supplied into beaker 1. Place the thermometer in the beaker of water. When the thermometer reading stops rising, record the temperature \(\theta_{1}\)
Start the stopclock and stir the water for one minute. Record the temperature \(\theta_{2}\) of the water
Calculate the temperature difference \((\theta_{1} - \theta_{2})\)
**Experiment B** (cooling with pouring)

Empty beaker 1. Pour approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water supplied into beaker 2. Place the thermometer in the beaker of water. When the thermometer reading stops rising, record the temperature \(\theta_{3}\)
Remove the thermometer. Carefully pour the water from beaker 2 into beaker 1. Pour the water back into beaker 2. Repeat this process **four** times
Place the thermometer in the beaker of water. Record the temperature \(\theta_{4}\) of the water
Calculate the temperature difference \((\theta_{3} - \theta_{4})\)
**Experiment C** (cooling with a lid) and **Experiment D** (cooling without a lid)
Empty both beakers

Pour approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water supplied into beaker 1. Place the thermometer in the beaker of water. When the thermometer reading stops rising, record the temperature \(\theta_{5}\)
Pour approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of the hot water supplied into beaker **2**. Place thermometer in the beaker of water. When the thermometer reading stops in
measure the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{g}}\)
Place the lid on beaker **1**. Start the stopclock. Allow both beakers to cool for 3 minutes
At the end of the 3 minute cooling period, record the temperature \(\theta_{7}\) of the water in beaker **1** and the temperature \(\theta_{8}\) of the water in beaker **2**
Calculate the temperature difference \((\theta_{5} - \theta_{7})\)
Calculate the temperature difference \((\theta_{6} - \theta_{8})\)
Rank the experiments in order with the one that produced the greatest temperature drop first
**greatest** temperature drop 1
**smallest** temperature drop 4
If this laboratory investigation is to be repeated many times to check the results, suggest one condition that should be kept constant in order to provide reliable results
A student complains that the investigation is not a fair comparison
Suggest one way in which the investigation could be made more fair
In this laboratory investigation, you will investigate the cooling of water by four methods
You are provided with a supply of hot water
**Experiment A** (cooling with stirring)
Place the sliding contact \(\mathbf{C}\) on the resistance wire \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a distance \(x\) from \(\mathbf{A}\), where \(x = 0.200 \text{m}\)
Record the value of \(x\) in Table 3.1
Switch on. Measure the potential difference \(V\) across the wire between \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{C}\). Record the value of \(V\) in Table 3.1
Measure the current \(I\) in the wire
Take the sliding contact away from the wire \(\mathbf{AB}\) and switch off
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of the section \(\mathbf{AC}\) of the wire using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
Record \(R\) in Table 3.1
Repeat the steps in **(a)** with the sliding contact at distances \(\mathbf{x} = 0.350 \text{m}\), \(0.650 \text{m}\) and \(0.800 \text{m}\) from \(\mathbf{A}\)
Plot a graph of \(R / \Omega\) ( \(y\)-axis) against \(x / \text{m}\) ( \(x\)-axis)
Using your graph, determine the length \(l\) of the resistance wire necessary to make a resistor of resistance \(1.2 \Omega\). Show clearly on your graph how you obtained the necessary information
Predict the resistance \(Z\) of \(1.50 \text{m}\) of the resistance wire. Show your working
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of a wire
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1 which shows the circuit that has been set up for you
You are provided with a length of resistance wire \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Place the lens a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the illuminated object
Move the screen until a sharply focused image of the object is seen on the screen. The screen and the illuminated object must now remain in the same positions during the experiment
Measure and record the distance \(v\) from the centre of the lens to the screen
Calculate the value of \(uv\)
uv =
Calculate the value of \((u + v)\)
Calculate a value \(f_{1}\) for the focal length of the lens, using the equation \(f_{1} = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}\)
Do not move the position of the screen or the illuminated object. Move the lens towards the screen until a smaller, sharply focused image of the object is seen on the screen
Measure and record the distance \(v\) from the centre of the lens to the screen
v =
Measure and record the distance \(u\) from the centre of the lens to the illum object
u =
Calculate the value of \(uv.\)
uv =
Calculate the value of \((u + v).\)
Calculate a second value \(f_{2}\) for the focal length of the lens, using the equation \(f_{2} = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}\)
A student suggests that \(f_{1}\) should be equal to \(f_{2}\)
State whether your results support this suggestion and justify your answer by reference to the results
statement
justification
State two precautions that you could take in this experiment to obtain reliable results
Sketch a diagram of the image seen in part (b)
In this experiment, you will determine the focal length of a converging lens
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 4.1
